questions.question_text:
A security appliance vendor is reviewing an RFP that is requesting solutions for the defense of a set of web-based applications. This RFP is from a financial institution with very strict performance requirements. The vendor would like to respond with its solutions.
Before responding, which of the following factors is MOST likely to have an adverse effect on the vendor's qualifications?

choices.B: The RFP is issued by a financial institution that is headquartered outside of the vendor's own country.
choices.A: The solution employs threat information-sharing capabilities using a proprietary data model.
choices.D: The vendor's proposed solution operates below the KPPs indicated in the RFP.
choices.C: The overall solution proposed by the vendor comes in less that the TCO parameter in the RFP.

discussion.content: Key Performance Parameters (KPP) are key system capabilities that must be met for a system to meet its operational goals.

questions.question_text:
A vulnerability was recently announced that allows a malicious user to gain root privileges on other virtual machines running within the same hardware cluster.
Customers of which of the following cloud-based solutions should be MOST concerned about this vulnerability?

discussion.content:
I think the given answer is correct
in an IaaS model, all you rent is the compute space, memory, and disks ONLY--the actual VM image is provided by you, the consumer. This gives you granular control of your OS version, patches, and system type. That would make it pretty unlikely that someone could gain root access to your system--you brought a custom kernel.
If you're leasing entire virtual machines (i.e. buying your licenses for your OS and machine images from your cloud vendor), I believe that is a PaaS solution (Windows as a Service, Linux as a Service, etc), and I believe that is the scenario being discussed in this question.

comments.content: Same, I would say D as well.
I think I actually agree with you on this one.

discussion.content:
Why not: D. Multitenant IaaS cloud?
Obviously multitenant would be exposed to more outsiders, and therefore be less secure. But why would PaaS be any less secure than IaaS? Arguably, SaaS may be of less concern, because it's not the customer's software (although it is the custom's datta). Also, SaaS may have some backup procedures.

B and C
B - Protects the integrity of the hosted OSs
C - Prevent VM hopping between VMs hosting sensitive data and non sensitive data.

VDI seems like a bad idea. From the question: "vulnerability exploited in one datacenter segment would not lead to the compromise of all others"
That is often a problem with virtualization. Compromise the hypervisor, and you can pivot from system to the next. This is the company's main concern. Using separate hardware would fix this.

Restraint: reduce the datacenter's physical footprint.
Concern-1: "integrity of operating systems"
B. Employ the use of vTPM with boot attestation 
Concern-2: "vulnerability exploited in one datacenter segment would not lead to the compromise of all others"
Maybe: E. Deploy to a private cloud with hosted hypervisors on each physical machine ?
I know, everybody thinks the answer to concern-2 is A. But I don't see where A really addresses concern-2. Whereas E seems to, at least somewhat, address concern-2.

It's A&B because the company is trying to reduce the number of pieces of equipment. Leveraging separate physical hardware would only add to the number of machines they have. B makes sense because if an attacker were to compromise a workstation, vTPM would be reset at the next reboot, so the attacker would not remain in persistence on that machine.

comments.content: Leveraging separate physical hardware might not add to the number of machines they have on site. The physical hardware could be offsite: private cloud, IaaS.

discussion.content:
C. Leverage separate physical hardware for sensitive services and data 
To me, this makes some sense. A specific requirement is "ensure a vulnerability exploited in one datacenter segment would not lead to the compromise of all others." If you use separate hardware, you will not have to worry about a hacker jumping from one virtual machine to another.
a&b is is the correct answer.

A,B ?
B: to mitigate the "concern about the integrity of operating systems"

questions.question_text:
An engineer is assisting with the design of a new virtualized environment that will house critical company services and reduce the datacenter's physical footprint.
The company has expressed concern about the integrity of operating systems and wants to ensure a vulnerability exploited in one datacenter segment would not lead to the compromise of all others. Which of the following design objectives should the engineer complete to BEST mitigate the company's concerns? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Deploy virtual desktop infrastructure with an OOB management network
choices.C: Leverage separate physical hardware for sensitive services and data
choices.B: Employ the use of vTPM with boot attestation
choices.E: Deploy to a private cloud with hosted hypervisors on each physical machine
choices.D: Use a community CSP with independently managed security services

choices.A: The ratio of phishing emails to non-phishing emails
choices.B: The number of phishing attacks per employee
choices.D: The percent of successful phishing attacks
choices.C: The number of unsuccessful phishing attacks

discussion.content:
C would complement what they already have which is the `Number of successful phishing attacks`. Also, including the "The number of unsuccessful phishing attacks" can easily allow them to get the 
* The ratio of phishing emails to non-phishing emails, 
* The number of phishing attacks per employee
* The percent of successful phishing attacks

If this were an exam question i would have chosen A. Firstly all CISOs are ratios and percentages driven. second, ratio of phishing to non phishing would show an increasing threat profile. This would be a good KRI. Then, from the phishing ratio, we can get the number of successful phishing attacks. Not sure if this is right or wrong but i'd chose that

I agree the answer is C.
If you're looking at N successful attacks, that doesn't give you the total number of attacks. The information needs to be supplemented with the number of net attacks, just not the attacks the are successful. Including the number of successful attacks and then percentage of successful attacks would also be confusing to report-readers, because they would see a decreasing percentage as the total volume of attacks went up and may not understand the correlation.

comments.content: The question specifically states: "Which of the following **additional** information . . ."

They are trying to find out if there has been "an increased number of cyber attacks."
The "percent of successful phishing attacks" would not really tell you that. If the number of successful attacks went up from 11% to 14%, that would not tell you if there were more total attacks.

discussion.content: I agree that D is correct, but so is C. If the # of successful phishing attacks is already being presented, and we add the number of unsuccessful attacks, we have the same information as the percentage.....

questions.question_text:
Company leadership believes employees are experiencing an increased number of cyber attacks; however, the metrics do not show this. Currently, the company uses `Number of successful phishing attacks` as a KRI, but it does not show an increase.
Which of the following additional information should be the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) include in the report?

choices.B: A MITM attack is being performed by an APT.
choices.D: An incorrect username or password was entered.
choices.E: A key rotation has occurred as a result of an incident.
choices.A: The SSH keys were given to another department.
choices.F: The workstation is not syncing with the correct NTP server.
choices.C: The terminal emulator does not support SHA-256.

discussion.content:
Why not: A. The SSH keys were given to another department? 
Seems as likely as an MITM attack.

comments.content: Reception and acknowledgement of the SSH key occurs before authentication.

discussion.content: Maybe: D. An incorrect username or password was entered?

questions.question_text:
An organization's network security administrator has been using an SSH connection to manage switches and routers for several years. After attempting to connect to a router, an alert appears on the terminal emulation software, warning that the SSH key has changed.
After confirming the administrator is using the typical workstation and the router has not been replaced, which of the following are the MOST likely explanations for the warning message? (Choose two.)
